- Wage increase doesn't offset the recent spike in cost of living expenses like gas, food, housing, etc.

review_title: A Train-wreck of a Retail Service Job

cons: The number of expectations that are pressed into each branch of worker is ridiculous. There seems to be no implementation of any proper source of training, complaint hotline, or any sort of benefit for the well-being of their employees. The workload and company-wide task list is consistently growing and, to the detriment of the employees, pressures continue to rise as well. Every manager or leader above me is receiving pressure from the executives above them and in turn I should have to pressure those under me. It is a branching tree of pointing fingers to blame someone for why work is not being done.

review_title: If you want to grow as a PM or IT professional, CVS is not for you
pros: CVS has many new business ventures which are very interesting. On the business side, there is a lot of learning and growth opportunities. The culture gravitates toward pleasant interactions. Rare to hear someone raising their voice or sounding threatening in virtual meetings. Leadership is strong but is overshadowed by the bureaucracy.
cons: The organization is terribly bureaucratic. The IT and PMO organizations are large and they don't operate from a position of driving value for the business. They assign PMs to projects and then do their best to work within a "go along to get along" culture, which is often not very impressive. Best practices from the PMI, Agile Framework, DevOps, or Lean Six Sigma are rarely talked about or followed. CYA is the name of the game. The Retail IT organization is 20 years behind in technology standards and has a confrontational relationship with the business.

review_title: They track everything. DO NOT use this job as an entry level IT job.
job_title: Technical Support Representative (RSSC) in Woonsocket, RI
pros: You do get two 15 minute breaks and a 30 minute lunch.
cons:
Training covered the basic hardware/software that you will be working with, but lacked in training for the actual job. They track everything. If you go to a restroom break, every second of that has to be logged. If you are seconds late from lunch, that is logged. You have to work one weekend day a week. You will work past your end time every single day. Because if you are scheduled to get off at 5:30, and it is 5:29, and a call comes in, you have to take that call. Every week has a different start time, so your schedule does not stay the same. You also have a different weekday off every week. 

I would never recommend this job to anyone trying to get into IT. You would be much better off focusing on building relevant skills to whatever IT job you want. You will not gain much relevant experience in this job.

job_title: Retail Store Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Depending on your store/district the people you work with can be a pleasure.
cons: The company does not really care about its employees, base pay is $13 and that's way too low when you consider what they ask you to do. Even just store associates will be running around the store trying to keep up with the huge amount of daily tasks, there is no such thing as just a cashier. On average I walk 7 miles a day in my store. Stores are also not given enough hours or there are not enough employees to staff more than 2 people per shift, my store can't even schedule 2 people per shift every day since our weekly budget doesn't cover it. Of course we're trying to hire but it takes about a month or more to get a new hire started which is insane considering how starved for employees the company is. For many stores the truth is you'll be struggling to keep up working crazy overtime while being berated by someone higher up for not being good enough all while be paid too little. Don't settle for less. For a company that's "helping people on their path to better health" CVS cares surprisingly little about the well-being of their associates.

review_title: Enjoyed the front end work and co-workers
pros: I thoroughly enjoyed working the front end register at my local CVS. Enjoyed interacting with the public, felt like I was making a difference in customer's lives giving them a cheery smile and some small talk when time permitted it and I sensed they wanted it. A lot of elderly customers who may not have a lot of social interaction in their day to day routines.
cons: It would have been more ideal if there was a fixed work schedule from week to week. Because the number of work hours and the days/times of those hours fluctuated greatly from week to week it made it very hard to have any kind of normal family or social life. I do understand, however, that it is virtually impossible for the store manager to accommodate everyone and still insure adequate staffing at key times, e.g., holidays. Also, although company policy said work schedules should be published 2-3 weeks in advance thereby allowing employees to negotiate changes with each other, our manager would frequently publish the schedule only a few days in advance, however, towards the end of my employment was improving the timing of work schedule postings.

review_title: terrible place to work rampant favoritism hard work and dedication get you nowhere
job_title: Shift Supervisor in Boca Raton, FL
pros: lifelong friends nothing else bad managment
cons:
This company is terrible to work for. I worked for the company for 15 years and it started as a very good company in the beginning.
I rarely called out was always called in and came in when I was needed. I always followed the rules and did a very good job, according to my other coworkers. co-workers would call out or just plain not show up and they would never get in trouble I was always on time very very rarely ever late. co-workers would leave the store whenever they wanted to. they would go home and sleep or not come in until 5 hours after the start of their shift and they never got in trouble because of favoritism by the manager and the district manager. the employee handbook and loss prevention is a joke as I never stole always paid for my items. the rules were flouted because they knew that the store manager wouldn't do anything I had other co-workers that would stay in the back room the entire shift to do a job that would take an hour on average to do but they stretched it out to 8 hours all the while looking up stuff on their phone. favoritism is rampant and you could be a great employee but if you get on the wrong side of the manager your hard work doesn't matter and you never do good enough they are supposed to have an "open door policy " but when I asked to use it After 15 years I was fired because I wanted to use the open-door policy and the manager just didn't want to hear it so he called the district manager so I was fired in those 15 years I ended up developing PTSD from the way I was treated by the favorite employees and I have been officially diagnosed with it a well from this job which has affected my jobs after the advice and counsel department is a joke as well as they ask for the employee's side of events but don't take and precedence in it and only listen the managers account of the situation they are far from impartial in their judgments also the systems in the store are archaic and cannot handle the actions that the company wants to be done there where many times registers would break and not be fixed for months on end

Cons
favoritism, hard work not appreciated, no employee loyalty, archaic tech, rampant superficiality

job_title: Pharmacy Technician Trainee in Cambridge, MA
pros: Exciting workplace, never a dull moment
cons: CVS will take advantage of you at every opportunity. They signed me up as a trainee to use me for the vaccine roll out and gave me minimal training, so I was not prepared to take the test. They also didn't tell me how to clock my hours differently when I was a Front Store Rx crossover so I wasn't paid as much as I should have been and my hours didn't count toward my license training. They don't care about your personal development, "metrics" come above everything else, and it's a job that wears at your mental health. They take on too much work for even a fully staffed pharmacy and this overworking takes a toll on everyone -- techs, pharmacists, customers. Also don't expect that you'll get to take a break. In your entire shift. If you're lucky, 15 minutes at most.

I find people get comfortable with being used. Get your 4 weeks of pay before they can you if you can’t work like a robot and get out of there. review_title: Made me realize I liked pharmacy work; horrible company
pros: They will literally hire anybody pretty much. I was hired without an interview even. This job made me realize I enjoyed pharmacy tech work and I have another job in this field now. Pharmacist would buy us food sometimes- donuts and what not which made us feel appreciated I guess.
cons: Where do I begin? First of all, I was hired no interview or anything because that’s how desperate they were (and still are). Which is a huge red flag. The store I worked at was so cliquey. There were two girls who did pretty much what they wanted and were rude. Customers are horrendous 99% of the time. Always busy, having to come in and stay hours and hours after close just to catch up. You’re not appreciated honestly. Just another body. Corporate doesn’t care about the people at all. We had to push flu shots on people and ask everyone who didn’t have one if they wanted one. So annoying. Couldn’t hold any employees the turn over rate is nuts. I walked out for my lunch break two months in and didn’t come back. Couldn’t handle it. Beware if you take a job here, honestly.

pros:
Benefits. 
- Decent PTO
- Holiday Pay
- 5% full 401k match
- Prescription Insurance is great. Maintenance medication is free.
- Education reimbursement is at 3k/yr.
cons:
- Health Insurance is only Aetna(CVS's company). Only High deductibles. 
- Dental Insurance only Aetna. 
- Career progression is only viable if you do not want a life outside of work. As you progress in the company you are expected to be working from the time you wake up to the time you go to bed. 
- Work load is insane when you progress inside the company. The higher you go, the more work the company expects out of you by under staffing departments and having the employees work more to get the work done instead of expanding their staffing. 
- Being noticed by management is only possible if you truly dedicate your life to work and being underpaid. Managers and directors have so many people reporting to them, you are lost typically in the crowd. 
- Once you are in the company, moving positions(promotions) are underwhelming salary wise. 
- Yearly raises, consider yourself lucky if you get anything above 2%.
- Recruiters are 3rd party, and have a terrible reputation within the company.
- Organization is a dream. From someone who was with the company for 7+ years, the organization and terrible communication only got worse.
- Everyone in management is worried about their job, so they keep information from their employees because if the employee is informed, they are seen as a threat to their job.

pros: Very collaborative and supportive team
cons: The onboarding for the department is the worst I have experienced. It took 4 weeks to get access to the laptop and an additional plus week to get email and other needed software/resources needed to do the job. There is NO formal training, you will get thrown straight from the frying pan into the fire. Some higher up leaders consider some parts of the department are considered “24 hour team” but there isn’t the staffing to support that unless staff are working 10-12 hour days and weekend hours  as well.

pros:
- Relatively Independent work as Store Manager
- Always active/moving
- Can branch into pharmacy if desired (recommended)
cons:
- Unrealistic Expectations: Told to expect excellence at all times from underpaid, overworked, physically threatened, and verbally harassed employees (including managers). 
- Conflicting messages from different departments (Asset Protection, District Leader, Etc.)
- Constantly removing ability to manage (limits to when you can work, how you make schedules, when you do resets, what vendors you have, what product you carry, etc.)
- Held accountable for sales/shrink despite HUGE influx in theft and inability to adjust what items are sold at your location (need District Leader or Regional approval that never happens)
- Bonus based on factors largely out of your control (external theft ALWAYS wipes out your bonus regardless of how well you do otherwise)
- Regular physical threats (personally threatened at knife and gunpoint multiple times and punched once over nearly 10 years)
- Poor work/life balance (District leader told me after being in position to expect at least 55 hour work week when position says it is a 45 hour per week role.)
- Pay is not great. On top of that, literally every other position outside of Store Manager (the Salaried employee working more than anyone else) was given an increase in pay either from State minimum or company tenure adjustment.

review_title: If I could give it 1 star I would…
pros: It’s a job that pays you. That’s about it.
cons: Corporate is the biggest issue I have with this company. They are incredibly slow but since COVID they are EXTREMELY SLOW. When I had my first interview there it took over a month before I could start working because of how long it took corporate to get me into the system. My boss told me the pay was $15 an hour, it was actually $11. I was promoted in less than a year but it took 4 months for my $11 salary to change to $13, though my manager had me working the duties of my promotion during that time. I waited A YEAR AND A HALF to see the back pay I was owed. I’m currently on a medical leave of absence and I’m still waiting for them to give me the sick time I accrued. They never have enough people working it was always only 2 people per shift working the store, we were always understaffed, stressed, and the only thing CVS cares about is us selling their monthly memberships. They do not care about their employees at all. If they did care I wouldn’t have needed to demand the money I was owed for well over a year. I do not recommend anyone work here, considering no one actually knows what they’re doing. It was an absolute nightmare and I look forward to never stepping inside another CVS as long as I live.

pros: This company literally has no pros. They don’t even care about their customers anymore.
cons:
I worked for the company for almost ten years. Started as a shift supervisor abs eventually became a store manager. They will do everything they can to pay you the least amount and work you to the bone.

When you move up from store manager in trying to store manager, they pay you less because they don’t take into account the OT you made and holiday pay.

pros:
It’s a fast paced job and there is always more to do.

They take care of sexual harassment claims swiftly.
cons:
It’s a capitalist hellscape. I’ve worked for CVS as a PharmTech for 7 years and corporate does not care about us. 

Stream of consciousness, NOT all inclusive:
You will never be fully staffed because corporate cuts hours so frequently that people can’t rely on the hours. And then, because you can’t staff the pharmacy properly, one hiccup and you are completely screwed. Say the pharmacist retires, then the other pharmacist gets covid. You now have no pharmacists with a vested interest in the pharmacy which means everything goes red, prescriptions take forever, phones are ringing off the hook, and there is a line of customers at both drop off and pick up. And you haven’t left drive thru in hours. 

You don’t earn a living wage even though this is an extremely difficult job (referring to it as a profession would be disingenuous given that CVS treats all of its retail and pharmacy staff like they are disposable) that requires a lot of training and multitasking. I have worked in a few stores and have seen many people come and go because it is too hard for most people.

There is so much more, including they do not pay a living wage to the techs who make the store viable. At the same time, they are handing out $100k signing bonuses to pharmacist (new techs may be able to get small signing bonus, $2k.) but nothing for the staff who have worked since pre-pandemic.

review_title: Would make a great first job
job_title: Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- direct team members and Rich B. are fantastic.
- fully remote work
- usually a simple technical interview about JavaScript/Typescript basics, nodejs basics, and angular basics to get hired.
- overall the work is pretty simple
cons:
- Aetna, the company you will work for, offers terrible insurance with high deductibles and high monthly costs. The plans aren't as good as former employers offered that used Aetna. They have a yearly employee survey that shows this is a major concern, and it is ignored every year.
- you have 7 vacation/sick days in total.
- We don't have the paid version of gitlab, so managing merge requests is a pretty manual process.
- We don't have a great ci/cd setup. Deployments fail for inconsistent reasons. This could probably be fixed by using the paid gitlab ci or paying to increase our Jenkins instances, but it is unlikely to happen.

review_title: Extreme metrics to the point of squeezing its staff to death.
job_title: Cvs Pharmacy Tech in Raleigh, NC
pros:
-You'll grow up fast and learn to hate people
-You'll see a new deep level of appreciation for small things like a 5 minute break or a pack of crackers
-You'll learn to pronounce complicated drug names and some people will think that is cool
cons:
-Extreme metrics with tons of negative reinforcements for not meeting them
-Dynamic hours
-Hours are heavily cut after flu-shot season and in the summer
-Base pay for a Pharm Tech is $16/hr ($33/yr) but you can really expect $24-25k/yr because of the cut hours as mention above
-Training? Good luck with that. You have to be a fast learner and multi-tasker because new hires are typically torn into the sharks after finishing their Orientation class
-Note to new hires: Orientation class is just a bunch of CVS propaganda and annoying ice breaking activities

review_title: Toxic Work Environment and Classist Culture
pros: CRGs, learn about health navigation, and benefots that are available (but unable to use).
cons:
Each August, hours go up . However, as March/April approaches the hours go drastically down. I've witnessed high employee turnover from hour cuts. The staff is working in a state of high anxiety. It is not healthy. It drains you of your mental and physical health. As a retail level employee, you seldom finish a day of work feeling accomplished. Instead, your day ends with a sense of feeling defeated.
While they do offer employee resource groups, retail staff are unable to become active members for their own growth. Talent is hidden at retail levels. This organization knows how to polish its glass ceilings (some enterpise and corporate colleagues), but ignore their dirty floors (retail level workers).
Under current conditions, I truly do not recommend CVS as a place of employment for anyone that I love or care about.

review_title: Easy job but culture depends on manager
job_title: Retail Shift Leader in Cincinnati, OH
pros: The job itself was not strenuous, I loved talking to customers and building a relationship with regulars. I became a shift leader early on after proving myself and once I had that position I found myself doing a range of tasks that kept the job more interesting. When I started managers had prizes and incentives for selling carepasses and pushed us to be our best in a fun way. I really felt taken care of (initially)
cons: The company did not have any response to understaffing following covid, other than pushing the existing workers to their max. No reducing store hours or bringing in employees from other stores, (my manager went out of her way to do this independently). It made the environment stressful and tense and nobody came into work happy. They're only now discussing competitive wages. Upper management is on salary and required to cover for gaps in the schedule or people missing work, which is not sustainable during a pandemic. I saw amazing managers pushed to their absolute wit's end and it ruined the culture.

pros: If you're trying to break into the healthcare industry, this is a great place to START on an entry level basis. It's also good for preparing you for high volume work environments & will teach you the art of organized multi-tasking; necessary experience if you want to work in healthcare at any capacity. You also have the opportunity to earn a licensed registration/certification title and learn a skill that you can take elsewhere and with additional education, you have the opportunity to evolve professionally.
cons: Very limited room for growth for both technicians & pharmacists. Your higher-ups will not care about you (their main focus is on numbers & you'll understand that if you decide to sign on with CVS Health) and if you're a technician, your career & financial needs will be completely ignored. Use this job as a stepping stone to your next career move. Use it to learn & grow individually, but if you decide to stay for the long run, don't expect any growth professionally.

pros: If you consistently need hours, they almost always have enough to go around.
cons: CVS is a dumpster fire I am expected to do two different jobs for less money than literally every other cashier for any other company. Management couldn't care less about the welfare of its employees. They never fix anything, the hardware we receive after something breaks is always at least a decade old so it breaks immediately. The only thing that matters to them is the amount of carepasses you sell. If you aren't selling enough, corporate couldn't care any less about you. If you are selling enough, they will congratulate you and then tell you that you should be selling 2 times that next week. And don't even get me started on the customers. Nastiest, most entitled, and thoughtless people I have ever had the displeasure of meeting. And every time you get a bad review, CVS won't actually read it. They'll just visit your store and start ranting about how your customer service rating has gone down. Take my warning, DON'T EVEN CONSIDER WORKING HERE. And if I seem like just another weirdo ranting on about a company I work for, go visit the CVS reddit page. I am by no means the only person who feels this way.

review_title: Company will not pay for adequate staffing, you are to blame
pros: Easy entry into the field
cons:
Overworked (will ask you to work at multiple locations), but will still be mad that you accumulated overtime.
Management will be upset if you do not pick up other employee's shifts when they call out.
Management thinks that only 17 tech hours is in any way adequate for staffing a pharmacy.
Pharmacy staff often has to operate front end as well as CVS cuts staff.
Whoever is in charge of closing the store is often by themselves the last few hours, which is dangerous.
Staff are not allowed to stop shoplifters, which incentives them to come back and be bolder. I have had people come in with literal duffle bags and stuff them full of items and walk out.
The people watching the cameras do not care if the cashier is being threatened, but god forbid you use the self-checkout to buy yourself a drink.
Beware any locations with public restrooms. I have had to clean blood off of walls on more than one location. Take that for what you will.

review_title: Please avoid for your own sanity
pros: You may get the opportunity to move up if your boss is desperate enough but they will definitely low ball your offer.
cons: Everything about management sucks from the store manager to the district leader. I’ve worked at several different stores and every manager has been self centered and egotistical. They care about no one else but themselves and never tries to accommodate their staff. They are also incredibly short staffed due to covid and refuse to shorten back hours causing burnout for everyone and stress. I’ve been with the company for three years and saw someone new come in and making more than me in the same position which broke my heart. I had a college degree and showed loyalty but a man made more just starting out. It’s sad how many times I’ve seen this happen with internal colleagues. While you get opportunities for growth, you’re better off going somewhere else because they won’t compensate you for what your worth. The job is stressful and tedious and not worth it.

job_title: Front Store Associate in Fairfield, CT
pros: Sometimes you get expired cough drops
cons: I was personally threatened by a customer and had to call the police while standing alone in the front with a long line of customers. Other than some basic texts in a groupchat the day of the incident, no further action was taken to ensure my safety or that of my coworker who was there with me and had to leave the scene of the incident due to literal hate speech from the “customer”. No meeting, no offer of links to company mental health care, nothing. Once a pharmacist came up to days later and expressed that she was sorry that happened but other than that it was not acknowledged. The pay is abysmally low for the amount of tasks one is required to perform each day, and I only got my two state mandated 15 minute breaks maybe twice my entire time there (2 months, roughly 4/5 days per week) because a manager felt generous. I would not recommend working here unless you have no other option and have a family to feed or a similar level of urgency. I had a poor experience with a stomach flu as well - I was expected to call out each day and find coverage myself.

job_title: Store Manager In Training in Fort Worth, TX
pros: -The first couple of months at my first store were bearable.
cons:
-At my second store, I was told to come to work while sick when I attempted to call out. I raised this concern with district leadership and they did not follow up, signaling that this behavior is acceptable.

-Also at my second store I was instructed not to inform asset protection of some of the activities that store leadership were engaging in. Again, the district leadership did not follow up with me when I raised this concern.

-The gossip I heard from my about the other in the training program by those who supervised him was unnecessary and unprofessional. District leadership also did not follow up on this concern of mine.

-Staffing constraints make the job impossible to complete without someone working 55+ hours a week on salary.

-Carepass is a convoluted program that we were required to sell and meet quotas on in order to hook customers into a monthly subscription to a pharmacy.

I was told upon hire that it would be 2, maybe 3 weeks, but most likely not 3 for orientation. That was just the start. Then when everyone finally was done and started working remotely ….it just steadily got worse. I was not given enough information or preparation for the role I had. They blind-sided everyone. They reprimanded employees for not being as efficient as required, but didn’t share an up front requirement to begin with. Managers and preceptors did a horrible job welcoming and training new staff, and at times were rude and hateful….to where u just thought about quitting every day. I have never worked as a nurse in any role where I was made to feel so low, inadequate or unappreciated. So much negative, little positive….do yourself a favor and pass this opportunity up….trust me you will save yourself months of stress and anguish.

pros:
Pay is alright, relative to other jobs
Feels nice giving people meds with no co-pay
cons:
You are owned by CVS. Some of this will be different by location, but at the CVS I work at 
We do not get the mandatory 15 minute break for working over 6 hours. 
It's impossible for full-timers to have a consistent time for lunch as the chaos of the workday interferes.
Your manager will have you make an availability schedule. It means nothing, and they will have you rewrite it numerous times until they consider it acceptable (acceptable meaning any time from open-close, in most cases).
You will have trouble sleeping at night after selling someone a month's supply of insulin for $1400 because their insurance stopped covering it -- all to make CVS and drug manufacturers bank.
The schedule will always be erratic unless you've earned enough seniority to demand a consistent one. Noon to eight P.M. one day could mean eight to five P.M. the next.
Corporate says "keep on chugging!" when a pharmacy filled with workers gets exposed to Covid-19. No precautions, no afterthought, just get back to work.

review_title: Worst company you could ever work for
job_title: Certified Lead Pharmacy Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: My store gave me flexible hours because I was friends with my pharmacist, but most of them aren't like that.
cons:
Everything about working for this company has been awful. They do not care about their employees and will pay as little as possible, even with experience (with their own company). They refuse to negotiate, it's "take it or leave it." My best advice: leave it. 

HR won't process promotions if they think the manager wants to pay you too much, and then won't tell anyone why there hasn't been any progress unless you harass them. As a technician, you'll probably make more money pushing carts at Target, I only stayed for pharmacy experience while I was applying for pharmacy school. If you're looking for a company that will drastically increase your workload and then cut available hours, CVS won't let you down. 

They also refused to give any hazard pay throughout the pandemic, despite deeming their employees essential. We got a minuscule bonus for the entire year, which they were so proud of. They are cheap and they don't care.

I have not met a single pharmacist, technician, store manage, or front-store employee that has been happy with this company. The stress is not worth it. They should not be allowed to associate the word "Health" in their name. 

Don't do it to yourself.

review_title: They use to care more about their employees.
job_title: Pharmacy Technicians in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Ability to work at other locations other than your “home” store. Merit raises given yearly after management does your evaluation. Paid sick leave is now given to all employees based on the number of hours they work.
cons: The CVS Company doesn’t seem to care very much about their employees anymore. I worked full time at the same location for 13 years and they cut our pharmacy hours so much that I was forced to go work at other stores to maintain full time status so I wouldn’t lose my insurance. If you don’t work at least 30 a week on average for 6 months you automatically get cut down to part time and then you lose your benefits. The benefits also used to be a lot better than they are now (very high deductible that includes going to doctors not just hospitals). Most the managers are fair, but there are some that are not so if you have a manager that just doesn’t like you for some reason they will cut your hours.

Would not recommend this job to anybody who values their peace of mind.

review_title: Not the worst, but could be way better
job_title: Sales Associate/Cashier in Mount Pleasant, SC
pros:
If you’re full time the benefits are pretty nice
You do get an employee discount, although it’s not very much and the employee card minimizes the type of coupons you get so you end up saving more with coupons from a normal card if you stack them right (20% for normal items, 30% for CVS Health items)
Flexible work shifts that accommodate school or other jobs
cons:
Expect the hiring and/or promotions to take 3-5 weeks for them to actually process all of your info. 
At my store in particular the district management refuses to fix the broken plumbing and A/C, so the bathrooms are constantly out of order and in the summers it’s hot the point that coworkers feel dizzy.
Raises are non existent I made only 11 cent my first and second year despite having a perfect record and doing above and beyond work tasks listed in my job description. Only way to increase your pay is by moving up in positions and even then you’ll only earn $1 more. We recently got pay raised to $13 minimum to compete with other stores, but that’s still extremely low when comparing to the housing market it my city.
They do payroll hour cuts often. Employees need 40hr/week to keep benefits and most don’t get that when CVS decides to do the cuts. Every year we get a hiring boom followed by an hour cut meaning you have to outcompete your coworkers in order to safeguard your own paycheck. Why bother offering good benefits if loyal, full time employees (speaking for my coworkers) can’t have the hours to qualify to keep their benefit plans?

review_title: CVS Pharmacy made it on the list of worse companies to work for
pros: I don't have any. The company sucks and the job sucks even more.
cons: I regretted working for this employer. Company is not lenient during the covid-19 so, expect not to be paid for calling out, especially when you have signs of covid. Terrible working conditions. The restrooms are always down, no scheduled breaks equals no breaks. I guess they haven't fixed the restroom as a way to deter workers from going on breaks. I counted four-weeks that the restroom is out of order, where are workers supposed to go for restroom breaks? Outside? on themselves?. There are no water in the breakroom for workers. The company is not big on workers' safety especially during covid-19. There are pixie glasses installed at each registers but that do not stop customers from peeking their face between the void. PPEs, such as masks, gloves, and santizers are not displayed for workers who choose to protect themselves. Workers should not have to ask for them, they should be required. I hated my manager he would talk about me to others acting like I don't hear him. I also hated the rotating pharmacists who act like they run the show. I hate to pay the Union who I haven't met or do anything for me. I struggle with the job during these months of hardwork so I can make a dime to pay Union fee who the Union representative haven't take initative to show their face.

review_title: Management will make or break your experience
pros:
-pay is good for pharmacists 
- 401 K is pretty good with 5% match
-lots of opportunities for leadership if you want to be a pharmacy manager since there is high turnover of pharmacy managers
-lots of opportunities for leadership even if you don’t want to be a pharmacy manager since your pharmacy manager is most likely overwhelmed and won’t mind if you help take some responsibilities off their plate
cons:
-Poor management can make your experience terrible. 

-There is poor or non-existent training given to new employees. Once you understand the system, you have it down, but some people don't see this job through for long enough to get to that point, which unfortunately leads to high turnover. Once you have learned enough, working at CVS is mostly okay as long as you have decent management. 

-Technicians are paid like crap, so CVS ends up losing a lot of good techs to other pharmacies willing to pay good techs what they are actually worth. Again, this leads to high turnover. And lots of their pharmacy locations being repeatedly understaffed. 

-scheduling can be inflexible and if you float, you may not get your schedule until a day before the next week starts, making life difficult to plan 

- UNDERSTAFFED! Corporate staffs pharmacies poorly and puts high expectations to do a lot with little to no staff. Of course, they know that in actuality, most of the stores are not accomplishing their lofty goals at all. Tons of stores with 99+ in QP, and this is just the 'norm' of the pharmacy. It is 'regular' for a lot of pharmacies to be operating in this manner. You just learn to be functional in a dysfunctional environment.

job_title: User Experience Designer in New York, NY
pros: It was interesting work for me
cons:
We celebrated people who worked while they were sick. In the midst of a global pandemic. In a healthcare company.

Toxic management and "throw your employees under the bus" culture.

White management, from the Midwest, is particularly mean to employees of Indian descent, who tend to hold lowest ranking roles. 90% of management is white and mid-western. Meaning, they live in isolated environments, where everyone looks, talks, thinks, dresses and behaves - like them.

Coastal communities are very poorly represented. And thus is, awareness of different cultures, tolerance, wordliness, etc.

They wouldn't know Diversity & Inclusion, if it hit them in the head. Someone once said in a call that they like a particular athlete, a tennis player. And another person criticized their choice and made them feel uncomfortable. So much so, that the tennis lover started apologizing and backtracking. Management said nothing during this whole ordeal.

review_title: Please consider the pros and cons (especially of a pharmacy with drive-thru and COVID testing)
pros:
Note that the following are based on my experience, and may or may not be specific to the CVS pharmacy that I worked at
- learned more about day-to-day operations at a retail pharmacy

- pay was higher than expected (partially due to raise in base pay for all pharmacy technicians just as I came in)

- some customers and coworkers were very nice, patient, and understanding
cons:
Note that the following are based on my experience, and may or may not be specific to the CVS pharmacy that I worked at
- poor training (endless modules that you are required to do and will probably forget; claims you should be fully trained after 2 months, but not having  a designated trainer; amount of on-the-job-training you'll get depends on if the pharmacist allocates time to train you or you take the initiative)

- COVID testing at stores with drive-thru  (people being late for appointments, not scheduling them early enough before travel and blaming you; holding up drive-thru and being blamed; not being properly trained before taking over drive-thru and COVID testing responsibilities)

- disorganized management (floater pharmacists can replace your regular managers any day = new way of doing things on any day; pharmacist-in-charge changed one month into employment; three different apps being used to convey important information, schedules, and for coworkers or pharmacist to request coverage or additional staff; giving schedules at irregular intervals and not scheduling enough workers [also fault of corporate cutting hours])

- understaffed (not having enough workers scheduled to begin with; callouts without coverage putting an extra burden on workers who came in; inventory tasks pile up [because never enough tech hours to get them done]; having hours cut and rarely being provided with more staff despite increased demands)

- unreasonable metrics that place an additional burden on staff without improving patient safety or care (answering phones, amount of vaccines given, taking all walk-ins for vaccines, manually calling patients to pick up their medications)

- ineffective rotation/sharing of duties (senior coworkers openly passing on less desirable tasks to newer hires and performing only more desirable tasks and/or less overall, with pharmacists being inattentive/too busy to care)

- unreasonable customers (you are not in control of how fast a lab processes COVID tests, if insurance covers a medication, if doctors all send their new prescriptions at once, or if a particular medication runs out of stock; but that will not stop them from yelling at you for it)

- physical demands (standing and/or walking for the entirety of your shift, taking out trash, unpacking inventory orders and arranging on shelves)

pros: If you like working with and helping people in a retail environment CVS Pharmacy might be a good match for you. I had a huge following of customers that would shop in my store just to come and see me. It enabled me to soak up a lot of positive energy and make my day bright.
cons: The pay could always be better.

review_title: Good Co-workers, but expect typical retail issues
pros: My co-workers were amazing, and unlike Walgreens, CVS will start you as just a pharmacy tech. In addition, unlike in regular retail, when I tell a customer that I can't do something (like refill a controlled substance Rx early) and they ask for my manager, the pharmacist will tell them the same thing. No managerial discounts. The pharmacy team usually is pretty tight knit.
cons: Typical retail problems: entitled and uninformed customers, corporate demanding tedious metrics and the sale of promotions that are unrelated to giving good pharmacy care. The maximum amount of man-hours a pharmacy can use is determined by corporate, and is usually far too few. When I left (August 2021), CVS was offering 12.50 an hour for a no-benefits, no consistent schedule, pharmacy tech position that required weeks of training and a state license. The Mcdonalds down the road (and many other restaurants) was offering 14-15/hr with the usual bonuses and promotions of a desperate company. Recently, CVS has committed to raising the wage of all employees to at least 15/hr.
